Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Coupling remote acoustic recorders and camera traps with crowd sourcing for monitoring (or surveying) vertebrate biodiversity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract EF 1450318 McShea

Understanding the relationship between animal abundance and composition and the characteristics and quality of their habitat remains a fundamental question in biology because of the challenges in adequately measuring the numbers and kinds of animals using that habitat. New tools and approaches are becoming available to remotely measure animals using sound and photographs that provide a window into nature not possible by conventional sampling methods. However these new technologies require new approaches to summarizing and synthesizing the pictures and sounds to convert them into meaningful information about animals. This EAGER is focused on tackling one of the most fundamental issues in measuring animals without using human observers or capture techniques.

This EAGER award will test questions about the relationship between animal productivity and biodiversity and evaluate the relationship between biodiversity and productivity at the habitat, site, and landscape scales. In addition the research will allow the assessment of how these relationships shift in different ecological networks, testing hypotheses where community composition is important. Each technology brings high-density complex data and unique processing challenges. The combination of data involves creative development of software, a data workflow to process and identify photo and sound data, and use of crowdsourcing to process the significant sound and visual data and expert review to implement quality control measures on the large amount of data collected. The crowd sourcing programs will involve many volunteers to identify mammals? photos and frog, bat, and bird recordings, revealing a hidden world of wildlife and educating these volunteers on the diversity that surrounds them. Results from the project will also be incorporated into existing Smithsonian outreach and educational programs that involve eMammal

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to develop a survey protocol appropriate for researchers in general but also specific to NEON to sample a broad suite of vertebrate animals using ground-based sensor arrays. We completed two summer field seasons of testing the survey techniques for large terrestrial mammals, frogs, bats, and breeding birds. We estimated local species richness by modeling occupancy probabilities from remote acoustic recording devices and camera trap data for terrestrial mammals, birds, bats, and amphibians. LiDAR data was used to assess habitat heterogeneity and hyperspectral imagery from satellite images to assess habitat productivity at multiple spatial scales. The total sensor survey effort was similar between all the targeted species groups with a minimum of 1,596 recorder nights for frogs and a maximum of 2,049 camera nights for large mammals. Citizen scientists were used to help identify camera images through the eMammal website and local birdwatching organizations aided to identify bird songs from the recordings. 10 frog, 97 bird, 7 bat, and 14 large mammal species were detected and identified.

We are currently modeling the relationship between each taxa and the habitat productivity and heterogeneity at each site the taxa were sampled. The results of these models show that different taxa respond to habitat productivity, water availability, and habitat heterogeneity very differently. For frogs, increases in water availability at a given site lead to increased frog species richness. For bats, increases in water availability, and undergrowth leaf area density show a slight increase in species richness. There are differences in response between grassland and forest birds. The grassland birds have increased species richness in drier areas with greater undergrowth leaf area density, while species richness of forest birds increases greater density of understory leaf area, heterogeneity in forest vertical structure, and the percent of ground cover. While our initial results show that the use of local habitat heterogeneity and productivity are useful when modeling species richness, the accuracy of the models varies depending on the scale used to make measurements. We are currently exploring these relationships at different spatial scales from 20 meters to 160 meters. These results could provide guidelines for conservation management mapping and give insight into what drives individual vertebrate taxon richness at local scales. 

As broader impacts from this grant we created the Soundburst software application to incorporate the acoustic data into the eMammal data flow developed for camera images and to test the utility of using crowdsourcing for species identification with sound files, which will be publically available for all to use. To help train the next generation of scientists with ecological field skills and computer analysis we employed several undergraduate student interns and a graduate student from George Mason University. Finally, the developed protocols can be adapted to successfully monitor NEON sites for multiple vertebrate taxon, that are not currently surveyed by NEON, across forest domain sites throughout the United States with little interference to existing protocols. By incorporating these methods to their annual surveys, NEON could develop a nationwide database on vertebrate diversity and activity.
